I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government has asked the Asian Development Bank (ADB) for project preparatory 
technical assistance (PPTA) to prepare the Vinh Tan 3 Thermal Power Project. The Fact-
Finding Mission, which was fielded from 4–15 June 2007, held discussions with officials of the 
Ministry of Finance, the Ministry of Planning and Investment, the Ministry of Industry and Trade, 
the State Bank of Viet Nam, and Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN) and visited project sites in Binh 
Thuan Province. The Mission reached an understanding with the Government on the impact, 
outcome, outputs, cost estimates, implementation arrangements, and terms of reference for the 
technical assistance (TA).1 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1. 
 
II.  ISSUES 
A.  Policy and Institutional Framework  
2.  The Government’s policy for the power sector, as enunciated in the Electricity Law, 
which came into effect in July 2005, is to develop a power market based on principles of 
transparency and competition so as to (i) achieve economic efficiency, (ii) attract investments 
from both state and nonstate entities to the sector, and (iii) ensure the legitimate rights of 
consumers and investors in the sector. The law declares that the state’s monopoly in the sector 
will be limited to power transmission, national load dispatch, and strategically important large 
power plants, leaving power distribution and nonstrategic power generation to potential private 
sector investors. Since the enactment of the Electricity Law, the Government has demonstrated 
its strong commitment to creating a transparent power market and to broadening ownership of 
the sector by taking several key steps, including establishing the Electricity Regulatory Authority 
of  Viet  Nam,  approving  a  road  map  for  establishing  a  power  market,  and  approving  the 
establishment of EVN based on a holding company structure.  
  
3.  The road map for establishing and developing an electricity market envisages a phased 
approach to reforms in the sector. During the first phase of development of the power market, 
competition  will  be  only  among  sellers  (power  plants),  and  a  single  buyer  will  act  as  an 
intermediary between the power plants and distribution companies. This single buyer will sell 
electricity to distribution companies and large consumers at regulated prices. A pilot internal 
power market limited to EVN plants was initiated in January 2007 and the power market based 
on the single buyer concept will start in 2009. The next phase of development of the power 
market, scheduled to start in 2014, will entail wholesale competition whereby sellers (power 
plants) and buyers (distributors and large consumers) will compete in a power market. The final 
stage  will  be  retail  competition,  whereby  retail  consumers  will  be  allowed  to  choose  their 
supplier.  
 
4.  The Government is restructuring EVN as a holding company. As part of this process, in 
April 2007, the Government approved an equitization plan for 2007–2008 for equitizing most of 
the operating units engaged in power generation and distribution. All existing power plants—
except the three multipurpose hydropower plants (Hoa Binh, Tri Anh, and Yaly)—and the nine 
regional power distribution companies will be equitized during 2007–2008. The thermal power 
plants and the hydropower plants are grouped into separate companies for the purpose of 
equitization.  The  four  power  engineering  consulting  companies  belonging  to  EVN  and  the 
subsidiary engaged in telecommunications services (EVN Telecom) will also be equitized. Prior 
to approval of this plan, two thermal power plants, a hydropower plant, and a provincial power

B.  Electricity Demand and Supply 
5.  Viet Nam’s economy has been growing at about 7.5% per year over the past decade, 
with gross domestic product growth reaching 8% in 2006. The Government is determined to 
maintain economic growth at a level of 8–8.5% during 2006–2010, the period of the current 5-
year socioeconomic development plan. A reliable supply of electricity is critical to sustain this 
level of economic growth, as electricity is central to almost every aspect of socioeconomic 
development, including job creation, industry, commerce and business, and people’s well-being. 
Following Viet Nam’s accession to the World Trade Organization in 2007, investment by both 
foreign  and  domestic  entities  has  increased  substantially,  with  new  businesses  being 
established at an increasing rate. As a result, demand for power grew by 20% during the first 
quarter of 2007, and this growth will continue with the establishment of new special economic 
and industrial zones. Electricity demand is anticipated to continue to grow at about 16% per 
year until 2011. As a result of this rapidly increasing demand, which is outpacing generation 
capacity,  Viet  Nam  is  experiencing  power  outages,  and  these  will  increase  unless  new 
generation capacity is added quickly.  
 
6.  Hydropower  plants  currently  account  for  about  40%  of  the  total  installed  power 
generating  capacity.  Given  the  rapid  growth  in  electricity  demand,  the  power  system  is 
experiencing low reserves during the dry season, when hydropower plants can only operate at 
about 40–50% of their rated output.Hence reserve capacities in the power system will be limited 
 
during the dry season from 2007 to 2011. During this period, the south, which has gas-powered 
power plants, can supply power to make up for only some of the deficit in northern and central 
Viet Nam(and at a higher transmission cost). Therefore, Viet Nam will have to import power 
 
from the People’s Republic of China and the Lao People’s Democratic Republic during the dry 
season. By mid-2010, southern Viet Nam will start experiencing a shortfall of about 600 MW per 
year in generating capacity, as power demand in the south is expected to grow by 10% per year.  
 
7.  The Government has started development of the natural gas-fired O Mon Complex 
Project. Natural gas reserves are estimated at more than 400 billion cubic meters (m3). Gas 
production was about 6.5 billion m3 in 2005 and is expected to reach 15 billion m3 by 2010. 
   
Currently, gas production is concentrated in the Nam Con Son Basin, located on the southeast 
coast. Almost all the gas produced has been committed for power generation in the Ba Ria and 
Phu My thermal power complex. The natural gas reserves from Cai Nuoc, and Block 46 fields 
are only sufficient to fuel the Ca Mau I (750 MW) and II (750 MW) combine cycle power plants in 
the Mekong Delta in southern Viet Nam, which are currently under construction. Commission of 
the Ca Mau I plant is expected in 2008 (testing of the gas turbine is ongoing), and commission 
of the Ca Mau II plant is expected in 2009. The proven reserves of natural gas from blocks B 
and 52 are sufficient to provide the 4.6 billion m3per year of natural gas required over 25 years 
 
to fuel the 2,850 MW O Mon power complex. However, construction of the O Mon power plants 
within the complex have been delayed because of protracted, ongoing discussions about gas 
prices with the investor.

8.  Viet Nam has a program to develop renewable energy to increase its contribution in the 
long term. Development has focused on off-grid power supplies in isolated areas with small 
hydropower, solar and wind power facilities. Both the Ministry of Industry and Trade and EVN 
have developed demand-side management and energy efficiency programs in recent years, and 
given  the  power  shortages  experienced  in  recent  years  and  continued  pressure  for  more 
electricity service, the Government and EVN are moving to strengthen and accelerate these 
efforts.  Nevertheless,  project  developers  have  identified  access  to  debt  financing  for  both 
renewable energy and energy efficiency investments as a constraint. ADB is working with 
domestic financing institutions to address this issue through appropriately designed lending or 
guarantee products and policy interventions making use of the proposed Energy Efficiency Fund 
and Carbon Market Fund. 
 
9.  Given the foregoing, and to meet the growth in electricity demand, the prime minister 
approved the Sixth Power Development Master Plan (PDMP6) in July 2007 to include new coal-
based generation plants in central and southern Viet Nam, in addition to the natural gas-fired O 
Mon Complex Project. Based on the revised PDMP6, EVN has prepared a list of new thermal 
generation capacity additions to the system between 2011 and 2015, including the Son My, Van 
Phong,  Vinh  Tan,  and  Vung  Ang  power  complexes.  All  these  power  plants  will  use  coal 
imported from Australia or Indonesia and will use super critical boiler technologies. As a result of 
these projects, the share of coal in the generation mix will increase from 16% in 2006 to about 
34% in 2020, while the share of hydropower will fall from 37% in 2006 to about 27% in 2020. 
The total installed generating capacity of thermal power plants will increase from 5,400 MW in 
2006 to 15,000 MW by 2020, making thermal generation a key source of base-load power 
generation.  
 
10.  About $23 billion in investment is required for the power sector during 2007–2011. In 
addition to its own internal cash generation, EVN will have to mobilize financing from other 
sources,  including  commercial  borrowing,  bond  issuance,  private  sector  participation,  and 
public-private sector partnerships, especially for generation projects. Development of the 4,000 
MW  natural  gas-fired  Phu  My  complex,  in  which  ADB’s  Private  Sector  Department  has 
participated  in  financing  two  plants,  is  an  example  of  a  successful  public-private  sector 
partnership. The Government recognizes the need for private sector participation in the power 
sector, and the private sector will develop the Son My 2 (1,200 MW) and Son My 3 (1,200 MW) 
thermal power plants within the Son My power complex. ADB is helping EVN finance the 1,000 
MW Mong Duong 1 Thermal Power Project through its public sector operations, and at the 
same time is assisting a private developer to finance the 1,200 MW Mong Duong 2 thermal 
power plant through its private sector operations. To meet the growing electricity demand, 
development of both O Mon gas power complex and Vinh Tan power complex is critical to 
ensure an uninterrupted supply of electricity for central and southern Viet Nam.  
 
11.  The Ministry of Industry and Trade has approved the preliminary feasibility study for the 
Vinh Tan power complex, the first coal-fired power plant in the south. The Vinh Tan power 
complex is planned to have a capacity of 4,400 MW, to be developed in three phases: Vinh Tan 
1 (2 x 600 MW), Vinh Tan 2 (2 x 600 MW), and Vinh Tan 3 (2 x 1,000 MW). A joint venture by 
the  Viet  Nam  National  Coal-Mineral  Industries  Group  (29%);  the  China  Power  Investment 
Development Corporation, Hong Kong, China (30%); and the China Southern Grid (41%) is 
developing Vinh Tan 1. Vinh Tan 1 is scheduled for commissioning by the end of 2010. EVN will 
finance  Vinh  Tan  2  in  2008  for  commissioning  by  2011  and  has  asked  ADB  to  consider 
financing Vinh Tan 3 in two phases. The first phase, the Vinh Tan 3.1 (1,000 MW) power plant 
would be financed by ADB in 2008 for commissioning in 2012, and the second phase, the Vinh 
Tan 3.2 (1,000 MW) power plant, would be financed in 2009 for commissioning in 2013.

4   
12.  The proposed Vinh Tan 3 power plant is consistent with ADB’s country strategy and 
operational priorities in Viet Nam. The power sector is identified as one of the key infrastructure 
sectors that require urgent assistance in the 2007–2010 country strategy and program for Viet 
Nam3 to avert a power crisis that may impede private sector investment in the country, a 
situation  that  will  worsen  if  not  addressed  quickly.  ADB  will  focus  its  future  power  sector 
investments in Viet Nam on generation and transmission through public-private partnerships, 
while EVN, with support from the World Bank, will finance the required distribution system. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
13.  The main purpose of the PPTA is to undertake the technical, economic, financial, social, 
and environmental study required to develop the Vinh Tan 3 Thermal Power Plant Project, to be 
financed by ADB in two phases.  
 
14.  The key outcomes of the TA include (i) confirming that the Vinh Tan 3 Project is the 
least-cost option for power generation as indicated in the PDMP6 and that it is economically and 
financially  viable;  (ii)  defining  the  project’s  scope,  cost  estimate,  and  financing  plan;  (iii) 
undertaking environmental and social impact assessment for the Vinh Tan power complex as a 
whole and ensuring that the power complex complies with national environmental emission 
standards and international best practices, such as those cited in the Pollution Prevention and 
Abatement Handbook;4 (iv) finalizing the environmental management plans and resettlement 
plan for the Vinh Tan 3 power complex; and (v) preparing detailed cost estimates and details of 
the  scope  of  work  for  engineering  consulting  services  to  be  provided  during  project 
implementation.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
15.  The TA consultants will review the prefeasibility and technical studies for the Vinh Tan 3 
Project and undertake the necessary analysis, bearing in mind the load growth prospects, the 
fuel mix, demand side-management and the resource constraints. In particular, the consultant 
will evaluate financing options and determine an appropriate borrower for the subsequent ADB 
loan (Government as a borrower for onlending to EVN or EVN as a borrower with a sovereign 
guarantee)  for  the  Vinh  Tan  3  Project.  The  consultants  will  also  provide  assistance  as 
necessary  to  the  Power  Engineering  Consulting  Company  2  in  preparing  the  detailed 
engineering designs and bidding documents.  
 
16.  To ensure compliance with ADB’s social safeguard policies in relation to involuntary 
resettlement, indigenous, ethnic minorities, and gender issues, the TA will review the social 
impact  studies  undertaken  by  the  Power  Engineering  Consulting  Company  2  and  the 
Guangdong Electric Design Institute to identify the likely social impacts of the proposed project. 
The consultants will include these impacts, along with remedial measures, in the resettlement 
plan. Public consultations will be carried out during the TA. 
 
17.  In accordance with ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment 
Guidelines  (2003),  the  consultants  will  conduct  an  environmental  impact  assessment  and 
prepare  a  summary  environmental  impact  assessment,  including  an  environmental

C.  Cost and Financing 
18.  The total cost of the TA is estimated at $1.176 million. The Government has requested 
that ADB provide $1.0 million. The TA will be financed on a grant basis by the Japan Special 
Fund, funded by the Government of Japan. The Government will provide counterpart staff, office 
space and facilities, technical feasibility studies, environmental reports, and support services. 
Appendix 3 presents detailed cost estimates and the financing plan. The Government has been 
informed that approval of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
19.  The executing agency will be EVN and the implementing agency will be the Thermal 
Power Project Management Unit 3. EVN will be responsible for overall implementation of the 
PPTA,  including  grant  administration,  review  and  approval  of  the  consultants’  reports  and 
payment requests, and communication with ADB. The Thermal Power Project Management Unit 
3 will be responsible for day-to-day TA implementation activities, supervision of consultants, and 
provision of counterpart staff and office space.  
 
20.  The TA will be implemented by a consulting firm that will provide about 26 person–
months of international and 24 person-months of national consulting services. The consultants 
will be engaged by ADB in accordance with its Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as 
amended  from  time  to  time).  The  TA  will  use  fixed  budget  selection  method  given  the 
importance of the project and the need for a high-profile consultant team for this relatively 
complex project. The request for proposals will include a matrix of consultant skills required for 
the project so that time and personnel inputs can be defined accurately. The PPTA will be 
implemented over a period of 8 months commencing in February 2008 and ending in October 
2008. The outline terms of reference for the consultants are in Appendix 4. 
 
21.  The consultants will organize three consultation meetings on environmental, social, and 
resettlement issues in Vinh Tan District, Binh Thuan Province, during implementation of the 
PPTA.  Estimates  indicate  that  about  200  participants  from  Government  agencies,  non-
government organizations, and concerned communities will attend the consultation meetings. 
 
22.  The final TA report will be disseminated to the public in accordance with ADB Public 
Communications  Policy  (2005).  All  computer  models,  databases,  and  training  materials 
developed by the consultants during the TA will be transferred to EVN upon completion of the 
TA and thereafter will remain the property of the Government.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
23.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Socialist Republic of Viet Nam for Preparing the Vinh Tan 3 Thermal Power Generation 
Project, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

I.  POVERTY ISSUES 
A.  Linkages to the National Poverty Reduction Strategy and Country Partnership Strategy 
The Country Strategy and Program 2006–2009 stresses the importance of maintaining sustainable, equitable economic 
growth momentum to achieve further reductions in poverty. Viet Nam’s success in bringing down the share of the 
population below the poverty line from 70% in 1990 to 27% in 2005 is based on rapid but equitable economic growth 
recorded during this period. The availability of cheap and reliable electricity generated from indigenous sources is an 
essential requirement for sustainable economic growth and for maintaining the economy’s international competitiveness 
as Viet Nam makes the transition from an economy based on agriculture to one based on industry. Viet Nam is also 
emphasizing the creation of nonfarm employment opportunities for the rural population through the provision of rural 
infrastructure, including access to electricity. Viet Nam has achieved considerable success in rural electrification, with 
more than 90% of rural communes and more than 80% of households having access to electricity. With access to 
electricity, the rural poor, who account for the majority of the country’s poor, will enjoy better education, communication, 
health, comfort, convenience, and productivity. In particular, the development of livelihood projects is critical for the 
sustainability of electrification projects, as livelihood projects will improve the income-generation capacity of rural 
households so they can pay for the electricity.

C.  Poverty Analysis

2. What resources are allocated in the PPTA/due diligence? 
 
The PPTA consultants will conduct a poverty assessment of the project, including a distribution analysis of project 
outputs, and identify the proportion of benefits accruing to the poor. 
 
3. If GI, is there any opportunity for pro-poor design (e.g., social inclusion subcomponents, cross subsidy, pro-poor

The incidence of poverty and the provincial government’s policies and strategies for poverty in Vinh Tan District, where 
the proposed project is located, will be analyzed and appropriate measures will be included in the project design to 
augment and complement government initiatives for poverty reduction in the province.

II.  SOCIAL DEVELOPMENT ISSUES 
A. Initial Social Analysis 
Based on existing information: 
1.  Who are the potential primary beneficiaries of the project? How do the poor and the socially excluded benefit from 
the project? 
 
Electricity is an input to most economic processes, and thus is an important ingredient of economic development, which 
is essential for poverty alleviation.  
 
2.  What are the potential needs of beneficiaries in relation to the proposed project? 
 
The proposed project will help provide an adequate and reliable electricity supply to satisfy the forecast electricity 
demand, including accelerated rural electrification initiatives. 
 
3.  What are the potential constraints in accessing the proposed benefits and services, and how will the project address 
them? 
 
The rural poor should be able to afford the electricity tariff. A discount will be provided to low consumption, poor, 
residential customers. 
B. Consultation and Participation 
1. Indicate the potential initial stakeholders. 
 
The potential stakeholders include residents in the vicinity of the project site, community-based organizations, and local 
government organizations. 
 
2.  What type of consultation and participation (C&P) is required during the PPTA or project processing (e.g., 
workshops, community mobilization, involvement of nongovernment organizations and community-based organizations, 
etc.)?  
 
Consultation workshops will be organized with stakeholders during the PPTA to help with project design and prepare a 
participation, consultation, and disclosure strategy for the project loan.  
 
3. What level of participation is envisaged for project design? 
         Information sharing          Consultation         Collaborative decision making         Empowerment 
 
4. Will a C&P plan be prepared?    Yes          No      
C. Gender and Development 
1. What are the key gender issues in the sector/subsector that are likely to be relevant to this project/program? 
 
There are no specific gender concerns in relation to this project. The provision of electricity will benefit everyone, 
including women.  
  
2. Does the proposed project/program have the potential to promote gender equality and/or women’s empowerment by 
improving women’s access to and use of opportunities, services, resources, assets, and participation in decision 
making?     
          Yes          No  The provision of electricity will benefit everyone regardless of gender.  
 
3. Could the proposed project have an adverse impact on women and/or girls or to widen gender inequality? 
          Yes          No   The provision of electricity will benefit everyone regardless of gender.

12   Appendix 4 
 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
A.   General  
1.  The implementation of the project preparatory technical assistance (PPTA) will require the 
services of a consulting firm to provide about 26 person-months of international and 24 person-
months of national consulting services. The consultants are expected to work closely with national 
experts from the executing agency, Electricity of Viet Nam (EVN), and the implementing agency, 
the Thermal Power Project Management Unit 3. They will have access to build-operate-transfer 
regulations and information pertaining to the proposed project’s feasibility study prepared by the 
Power Engineering Consulting Company 2. 
 
2.  The team leader will ensure that the technical assistance (TA) is undertaken in an efficient 
and effective manner. The team leader must work for the project on a full-time basis, be located in 
Viet Nam for the duration of the study, and must have the authority to act on the firm’s behalf to 
achieve the objectives of the TA. Other members of the team should have sufficient breadth and 
depth of skills to minimize the number of individual team members, thereby enhancing efficiency 
and adding coherence to project delivery. Individual consultants can cover more than one skill area, 
in which case their curriculums vitae will be evaluated independently for each of the skill areas 
covered. 
 
B.   Required Expertise and Tasks 
 
1.  Power System Planning and Engineering Specialist (team leader, international, 
8 person-months) 
 
3.  The consultant should have an educational background in power engineering and at least 8 
years  of  international  experience  in  power  system  planning  and  engineering,  preferably  in 
Southeast Asia. The consultant will  
 
(i)  review and validate EVN’s demand forecasts, including the load pattern, for the 
entire country; 
(ii)  review the  master plan and least-cost generation expansion planning of EVN’s 
power system and confirm that the proposed investment is the least-cost generation 
option; assess the merit order of the plant in the power market and transmission 
issues that may impede its market access;  
(iii)  prepare project cost estimates, including unit costs and estimates of quantities for 
project components;  
(iv)  conduct risk analysis using the World Bank’s risk assessment method for power 
utility planning;  
(v)  prepare (a) a draft logical framework for the ensuing Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
loan,  and  (b)  the  implementation  schedule  for  each  component,  including  key 
procurement milestones;  
(vi)  assess the project's technical risks and its viability by means of sensitivity analysis; 
and  
(vii)  draft the terms of reference, determine expertise requirements, and estimate the 
number of person-months required for project implementation consulting services.  
 
2.  Project Economist (international, 6 person-months) 
 
4.  The consultant should have an educational background in economics and at least 8 years 
of international experience in power generation projects. The consultant will

Appendix 4   13
 
(i)  determine the linkages between electricity demand growth, economic growth, and 
poverty reduction;  
(ii)  review the Government’s national poverty reduction strategy and provincial poverty 
reduction interventions and comment on the role of power generation projects in 
poverty reduction;  
(iii)  calculate the long-run marginal cost of supplying electricity to different consumer 
categories and the full financial cost-recovery tariff; 
(iv)  review the national demand forecast for electricity and the underlying assumptions;  
(v)  reviewing the least-cost generation expansion plan for Viet Nam and identify the role 
of gas-fired thermal power plants and the ranking of the proposed project among 
thermal power projects in the overall expansion plan;  
(vi)  verify that the proposed project is part of the least-cost plan for meeting demand for 
electricity in light of a proposed competitive wholesale market in Viet Nam;  
(vii)  prepare regional and provincial load forecasts and demand and supply balances for 
the next 5 years for south Viet Nam taking transmission constraints into account;  
(viii)  identify alternatives to the project, including electricity imports from neighboring 
countries through the proposed Greater Mekong Subregion power grid, for meeting 
the demand for electricity in the south and establish that the project is the least-cost 
option for meeting regional demand; 
(ix)  identify  the  economic  costs  and  benefits  of  the  proposed  project  after  making 
adjustments to remove the effect of price distortions; 
(x)  undertake a distribution analysis of project outputs and identify the proportion of 
benefits accruing to the poor; and  
(xi)  coordinate  the  economic  analysis  work  with  the  power  system  planning  and 
engineering specialist. 
 
3.  Project Financial Analyst (international, 4 person-months) 
 
5.  The consultant should have an educational background in finance and at least 8 years of 
international  experience  in  undertaking  financial  analyses  of  power  generation  projects.  The 
consultant will  
 
(i)  review the historical financial performance of EVN and its compliance with previous 
loan financial covenants, propose new prudential financial covenants if needed to 
ensure the sector’s financial sustainability, and propose tariff levels that will achieve 
compliance with these covenants;  
(ii)  prepare cash flow forecasts for the proposed project and evaluate the weighted 
average cost of electricity generation in relation to existing capacity; 
(iii)  prepare cost estimates, including price and physical contingencies for the proposed 
project;  
(iv)  evaluate  financing  options  and  determine  an  appropriate  borrower  for  the 
subsequent ADB loan (Government as a borrower for onlending to EVN or EVN as 
a borrower with a sovereign guarantee), and  
(v)  assess EVN’s financial management capabilities, budgeting procedures, internal 
control procedures, and internal and external audits procedures and recommend 
measures to improve its financial management capabilities. 
 
4.  Social Assessment and Resettlement Specialist (international, 4 person-months) 
 
6.  The  consultant  should  have  at  least  5  years  of  experience  in  undertaking  social 
assessments of power generation projects in Southeast Asia. The consultant will

Appendix 4   15
 
(ix)  conduct stakeholder consultation meetings, including preparing the minutes of such 
meetings to record substantive discussions and compiling records of attendees; and 
(x)  assess the project’s impact in terms of carbon dioxide emissions. 
 
6.   Power System Planning and Engineering Specialist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
8.  The consultant should have an educational background in energy economics and at least 6 
years of experience in power system planning and economic analysis in Viet Nam. The consultant 
will  
 
(i)  review energy sector policies and regulations and identify critical issues that need to 
be addressed;  
(ii)  identify incentives for energy source diversification and investment promotion and 
develop a list of such incentives for short- to medium-term planning periods;  
(iii)  assess  EVN’s  least-cost  generation  expansion  plan  and  its  transmission  and 
distribution systems; 
(iv)  prepare  an  assessment  report  based  on  institutional  analysis  and  identify 
constraints for the power sector; and 
(v)  assist with (a) preparing a summary report of energy resource development options, 
including potential hydroelectric- and fossil fuel-based power generation, and (b) 
suggesting improvements to transmission and distribution systems. 
 
  7.  Project Economist (national, 8 person-months) 
 
9.  The consultant should have an educational background in economics and at least 6 years 
of experience in power system planning and economic analysis in Viet Nam. The consultant will  
 
(i)  collect data and review electricity tariffs and related issues;  
(ii)  help the international consultants prepare short-term (3-year) and long-term (system 
planning period) demand forecasts for different consumer categories;  
(iii)  assist  the  international  consultants  in  assessing  EVN’s  least-cost  generation 
expansion plan and its transmission and distribution systems;  
(iv)  liaise with  government institutions, such as the Ministry of Industry and Trade, EVN, 
the Institute of Energy, and power engineering consulting companies, to exchange 
information and ensure that information and data are up-to-date; and  
(v)  help run simulations of expansion planning scenarios to determine the economic 
benefits of the proposed project. 
 
8.   Resettlement and Social Assessment Specialist (national, 4 person-months) 
 
10.  The consultant should have at least 6 years of experience with power generation projects in 
Viet Nam. The consultant will  
 
(i)  assist with collecting socioeconomic data and all other relevant information for the 
social, gender, and poverty assessments;  
(ii)  assist in organizing consultation meetings with stakeholders and help prepare the 
participation, consultation, and disclosure strategy for the project loan;  
(iii)  assist with drafting the terms of reference for a social development and resettlement 
specialist who will monitor implementation of the resettlement plan; and  
(iv)  assist with stakeholder consultations. 
 
9.   Environment Specialist (national, 4 person-months)

16  Appendix 4 
 
 
11.  The consultant should have at least 6 years of experience with power generation projects in 
Viet Nam. The consultant will  
 
(i)  conduct site visits and assist with preparing the scope of work for undertaking an 
EIA and preparing an EMP;  
(ii)  assist with the collection of baseline environment data;  
(iii)  help draft the EIA and the summary environment impact assessment and submit 
them to EVN and ADB for review;  
(iv)  assist in organizing consultation meetings with stakeholders; and  
(v)  coordinate closely with the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment and the 
provincial Department of Natural Resources and Environment in ensuring that the 
EIA  and  summary  environmental  impact  assessment  are  acceptable  and  in 
compliance with Government and ADB requirements. 
 
C.   Reporting Requirements 
 
12.  The  consultants  will  prepare  reports  in  English,  with  summaries  related  to  social  and 
resettlement issues translated into Vietnamese as appropriate. All reports will be submitted in both 
electronic and paper form to ADB and EVN. All data and analyses will be consolidated and 
provided to EVN in electronic form. 
 
13.  The consultants will prepare a final report and the following administrative reports: (i) an 
inception report 1 month after commencement of the study, and (ii) an interim report at the end of 
month 4.  
 
14.  In addition, using standard ADB Board document formats and guidelines, the consultants 
will draft the following: (i) ADB safeguard documents (resettlement, social, and environmental); (ii) 
Board documents for a proposed TA loan (or equivalent) for detailed project preparation; and (iii) 
Board documents for a loan investment project. 
 
15.  The consultants will organize stakeholder consultation meetings on social resettlement and 
environmental issues during the TA period.
